content.div:
Sure, Nicki Minaj's evil spirits were exorcized on Grammy night -- but what about the rest of us?! All of us tortured mortals remain agonized over the memory of that chaotic, sacrilicious spectacle. What are we, the innocent, music-loving public, supposed to do? Because we can tell you right now, all the Jesus Juice in the world didn't make that Grammy moment disappear. (And we were taking a swig every time somebody said the word "Whitney.")

We forgive Minaj, though. It would be hard not to, really -- the Pink Friday MC seems to be making such an effort to be contrite. She debuted a song called "Starships" today, for instance -- and, maybe if we cross our fingers and say 10 rosaries, it'll put the MC back on track.

Produced by Lady Gaga co-conspirator RedOne, and packed with Euro-dance synths and a summery, Top 40-ready chorus, this is hardly Minaj at her fiercest. It's more like Minaj at her Taio Cruz-est. Still, "Starships" doesn't involve samples from West Side Story -- or a choir singing "O Come All Ye Faithful." Even if you sorely miss the Nicki Minaj of "Monster," take this as a small mercy.

"'Starships' is one of my absolute, absolute favourite records on Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded," Minaj said on Ryan Seacrest's radio show today -- which would account for her next statement. "It just sounds like a Ryan Seacrest-type of record. And I’m so excited for you to give this song your blessing, Ryan, because I know people are gonna love it."

It's worth nothing that Seacrest did not, however, play the part of the priest in Minaj's "Exorcism of Roman" Grammy number.

She continued: "It feels right. It just feels good. It makes people feel happy and that’s all I want. I want to start the year off with making people feel good. The [Grammy] performance was the performance, that was my clear craziness, and now it’s time to make people dance and have fun, and that’s all I want to do.”

Nicki Minaj's Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded is expected to arrive April 1.

Listen to "Starships" below:

leahc@dose.ca

entry.title: 2012 Grammy Awards - Best and Worst Moments

link.Abstract: It's music's biggest -- and longest -- night. Adele, Foo Fighters, Whitney Houston and more made for some of the most memorable moments of the 54th Annual Grammy Awards.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract:
As music's biggest night, the Grammys' mantra has always been about paying tribute to music's biggest stars. Typically, though, they're in the audience -- collecting more trophies than their Versace-clad arms can carry. That was certainly true of Sunday's edition -- with the likes of Adele, Kanye West and the Foo Fighters being lauded. But there was a heavy note to this year's show, broadcast the day after Whitney Houston's passing. The six-time Grammy winner was remembered throughout the evening, but that didn't stop the 54th Annual Grammy Awards from being the marathon, three and a half hour party it always is. Check out some of the highlights.
--Leah Collins/Dose.ca
link.title: As music's biggest night, the Grammys' mantra has always been about paying tribute to music's biggest stars. But there was a heavy note to this year's show, broadcast the day after Whitney Houston's passing. The six-time Grammy winner was remembered throughout the evenin
